;周六晚上，数千名音乐爱好者聚集在香港湾仔海滨，欣赏耗资 4,000 万港元的 Harbour Chill Carnival 拉开了帷幕，这是政府为振兴这座城市而组织的为期五个周末的计划的一部分。

;

;但是，由于舞台搭建在离岸驳船上，所以只有站着的人前排可以看到表演者和数十名歌迷爬上栏杆，以便清楚地观看音乐会，音乐会由粤语流行歌手陈慧琳拉开序幕。

;

;Becca Shi，23 岁来自深圳的一位四岁游客前往这座城市观看她的偶像陈的表演。

;

;她在小红书（类似 Instagram 的社交媒体平台）上了解到此次活动后，尝试在线预订门票

;

;不过她表示，有朋友成功拿到了两张门票。

;

;“这里氛围很好，充满激情和活力。陈凯莉是我童年的一部分，”她解释道。 “但舞台离看台真的很远。”

;

;40多岁的香港居民曾美仪(Bee Tsang)与朋友一起观看了演唱会，他表示这次经历很令人失望，他想抵达后不久就离开。

;

;“香港自称为国际城市，却举办如此高质量的音乐会，真是太遗憾了，”从事金融工作的曾先生说。

;

;“我们不得不在炎热的天气里走很长一段路才能到达这个区域......而且我们几乎看不到舞台，驳船低于视线水平。”

;

;曾表示组织者应该选择中环海滨或其他设施齐全的政府运营场地举办音乐会。

;

;香港歌迷在几分钟内抢购 14,000 张 Harbour Chill Carnival 免费门票

;

;10 场免费音乐会中的第一场从周六开始的五个周末，城市女子组合 Lolly Talk 和男子组合 Nowhere Boys 也亮相。

;

;香港歌手陈柏宇和台湾歌手 Hush 也参加了活动的后半场。< /p>;

;音乐会开始前大约半小时，音乐会观众聚集在海滨音乐会区，一些人举着霓虹灯牌以示对偶像的支持。

;

;前两个音乐会周末的 14,000 张免费门票7月8日至9日和15日至16日，上周二半小时内就被抢购一空。

;

;买不到票的人仍然可以在湾仔码头旁边的大屏幕上观看演出，现场直播-直播了整个活动。

;

;数百人聚集在屏幕区域观看表演，并享用嘉年华设立的六个小吃摊的小吃和饮料。

;

;香港人受邀与泰森一起放松耀西在价值4,000万港元的海港嘉年华上表演

;

;码头旁还举行了街头表演，包括杂技、舞蹈、X-game、滑板和功夫艺术。

;

;香港精英滑板手陆俊贤是码头的表演者之一。

;

;“在这里表演感觉很棒。这是一次难得的在繁忙的市中心玩滑板、与公众接触的机会。”他说。

;

;“这次活动也让我能够与海外运动员交流，进一步弘扬滑板文化。”< /p>;

;由香港旅游发展局主办的嘉年华系列将在接下来的四个周末，从金紫荆广场到红磡海底隧道，于星期日及星期六及星期日继续举行，并承诺会有更多精彩活动。< /p>;

;在中国大陆的香港学生预计将填补该市半校的名额一位行业领导者表示，在直接补贴计划 (DSS) 覆盖的机构入学率达到 2007 年以来的最低点后，私立学校的入学率下降了。媒体平台向家长和学生展示如何进入该市的一些顶尖学校。

;

;去年 9 月的政府统计显示，该计划覆盖的 59 所中学有 43,892 名学生入学，这让机构拥有更多自由与其他政府资助的学校相比，他们可以选择课程、费用和入学标准。

;

;这些学校被认为是该市中等收入家庭的热门选择，旨在为孩子提供出国留学的机会，因为院校可以提供非本地课程，例如国际文凭课程和英国 GCE A-level 课程。

;

;香港学校被告知将中一班级的“上门”名额减半

;< p>;一份入学统计报告称，此类学校的入学率创16年来新低，且连续三年下降。

;

;2021-2022学年半私立学校的入学率为44,636 名学生，较上年的 45,586 名有所下降。

;

;香港直接资助计划学校议会主席陈志安周六表示，学校的部分名额已被内地学生填补随着二月份跨境旅行限制的放松。

;

;“我们看到今年内地学生向学校申请的数量明显增加，”他说。

;

;身兼英华书院校长的陈先生补充说，退学的学生人数从上学年的“几十人”下降到本学年的“十人左右”。

;< p>;他说，一些离开的学生已经移民到其他国家或转学到国际学校。

;

;资助中学议会主席李宜英表示，该组织一些最受欢迎的院校边境重新开放后，也收到了不少内地学生的申请。

;

;“但他们是生活在内地的香港学生，所以他们都有资格到香港公立学校读书。”她说。

;

;李补充说，政府在12月推出的顶尖人才通行证计划也为资助学校引进了另一批学生，但指出目前数量未知。

;

;政府在今年 9 月完成下一次人数统计后，预计来自内地的学生涌入程度将在明年的报告中披露。

;

;香港学校因移民而减少 33,600 人，但官员仍保留乐观

;

;类似 Instagram 的中国社交电子商务平台小红书上的个人资料正在分享学生如何准备香港公立和私立校园（从幼儿园到中学）面试的技巧。< /p>;

;平台上的一些教育中介还提供“一站式”服务，帮助家长从头开始报名学校。

;

;帖子中包含学费、申请期限等详细信息

;

;香港私立学校面临倒闭，首推移民潮为原因

;

;“直资学校的教育资源香港的国际学校的教学质量远远优于大多数政府资助的学校，而且学费也低于香港的国际学校。因此，他们是很多新移民家长心中的热门选择。”一位中介写道，他声称已帮助超过1000名家长进入该市名校。

;

;另一则帖子列出了涵盖的10所学校该计划适合“内地新移民”，并补充说：“如果父母成为城市居民，让孩子进入香港学校并不困难。”

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Ukraine vows it will not use cluster munitions in Russiahttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3227036/ukraine-vows-it-will-not-use-cluster-munitions-russia?utm_source=rss_feed

;乌克兰国防部长奥莱克西·雷兹尼科夫 (Oleksii Reznikov) 对美国向基辅运送集束炸弹的决定表示欢迎，他说它将有助于解放乌克兰领土，但承诺这些弹药不会在俄罗斯使用。

;

;美国周五宣布，将向乌克兰提供广泛禁止的集束弹药，以用于对俄罗斯占领军的反攻。

;

;美国周五宣布，将向乌克兰提供广泛禁止的集束弹药。 >;

;雷兹尼科夫表示，这些弹药将有助于拯救乌克兰士兵的生命，并补充说乌克兰将严格记录其使用情况并与合作伙伴交换信息。

;

;美国将向乌克兰发送集束弹药，吸引来自人权组织的批评

;

;“我们的立场很简单——我们需要解放我们暂时占领的领土并拯救我们人民的生命，”雷兹尼科夫在推特上写道。

;

;“乌克兰将使用这些弹药只是为了解除对我们国际公认领土的占领。这些弹药不会在俄罗斯官方承认的领土上使用。”

;

;100多个国家禁止使用集束弹药。它们通常会释放大量较小的炸弹，可以在大范围内不分青红皂白地造成杀伤。那些未能爆炸的会造成数十年的危险。

;

;莫斯科周六再次批评美国的决定，称其为华盛顿“反俄罗斯”方针的又一个“令人震惊”的例子。

;;

;美国总统乔·拜登的国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文周五寻求向乌克兰提供武器，以收回自俄罗斯 2022 年 2 月入侵以来夺取的领土。

;

; “我们认识到集束弹药会造成未爆炸弹药造成平民伤害的风险，”沙利文告诉记者。 “但是，由于乌克兰没有足够的火炮，如果俄罗斯军队和坦克越过乌克兰阵地并占领更多乌克兰领土并征服更多乌克兰平民，也存在造成平民伤害的巨大风险，”他说。

;

;雷兹尼科夫表示军队不会在城市地区使用集束弹药，只会使用它们“突破敌人的防线”。

;

;俄罗斯、乌克兰和美国尚未签署《集束弹药公约》，该公约禁止生产、储存、使用和转让武器。

;

;该公约签署国西班牙表示反对这一决定。

;

;“西班牙基于坚定的承诺西班牙国防部长玛格丽塔·罗伯斯周六在马德里集会上对记者表示：“英国与乌克兰有坚定的承诺，即在任何情况下都不能运送某些武器和炸弹。”

;

;英国也是该协议的签署国。总理里什·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 表示，该公约禁止生产或使用集束弹药并阻止其使用。

;

;“我们将继续尽自己的一份力量，支持乌克兰抵御俄罗斯的非法无端入侵，”他告诉记者周六记者。

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank says it found no evidence it is dominated by Communist Partyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3227034/chinese-led-asian-infrastructure-investment-bank-says-it-found-no-evidence-it-dominated-communist?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 22:10;
;;

;中国主导的亚洲基础设施投资银行（AIIB）表示尚未发现任何证据在前通讯主管高调辞职后，共产党的影响力受到了影响。

;

;该银行周五表示，在加拿大国民鲍勃·皮卡德公开辞职后，该银行立即启动了审查，称该银行“此次审查于 6 月 15 日至 26 日期间进行，由亚投行总法律顾问、巴西公民阿尔贝托·尼尼奥 (Alberto Ninio) 领导。

;

; p>;

;Ninio 表示，审查发现“没有证据支持或验证”指控。

;

;该银行表示，在“全面审查文件材料”和 30 多项文件后，皮卡德的指控“不正确且未经证实”。采访了包括银行行长、高级管理层和员工在内的高级职位。

;

;它表示，没有证据表明“来自任何国家的任何政党的工作人员”干扰了绩效，而且从来没有任何关于政治影响决策的指控。

;

;但皮卡德驳斥了这项审查，称其为“笑话”，并将其与“袋鼠法庭”进行比较。

;

;加拿大立法者否认他的报道。该银行于 2016 年在北京成立，为铁路和其他基础设施项目提供融资，有时被描述为美国领导的世界银行和亚洲开发银行的中国替代品。

;

;中国是亚投行最大的捐助国，拥有约26.5%的投票权。

;

;亚投行有106个成员，其中包括大多数亚洲国家以及加拿大、俄罗斯、法国和英国。不过，日本和美国不是成员。

;

;该银行表示，此次审查是由 10 名员工组成的“跨国且性别平衡”小组进行的，并就加强领导层招聘流程提出了建议

;

;其中包括“强制性的全面背景调查、至少对最近五个组织的背景调查，包括领导力概况评估，以及改善”员工申诉机制的运作。”

;

;皮卡德告诉《华盛顿邮报》：“他们仍然认为我的指控毫无根据，现在他们发表了一份垃圾报告，充其量是一堆不光彩的谎言和半真半假的内容。

;

;“[亚投行]用低品格的调查结果来贬低我，比如说他们会改善未来招聘的背景调查，就好像我看到他们的真实面目有问题一样。”

;

;他还坚持自己的指控，即银行该行行长金立群曾担任中国财政部副部长，并在其 31 名高层中总共担任过 8 名。领导职务由中国公民担任，其中包括五名曾在财政部工作过的人。

;

;他们负责监督组织内的重要运作，包括政策、预算以及主权和非主权贷款。

;< p>;在回答有关审查的问题时，亚投行表示“透明度对于我们 106 个成员、我们的多边同行、我们的发展伙伴、我们的民间社会组织以及我们所服务的公民的信任至关重要。”

;

;皮卡德的辞职引发了加拿大和中国之间的争吵，驻渥太华大使馆表示这些指控“纯粹是耸人听闻的炒作和彻头彻尾的谎言。”

;

;北京外交部表示，该银行遵守“在招聘和管理员工时遵循“公开、精英和透明的原则”。

;

;但加拿大副总理兼财政部长克里斯蒂亚·弗里兰表示，该国将停止亚投行所有“政府主导的活动”，并已开始审查

;

;由于共产党的指控，加拿大停止了亚投行“政府主导的活动”

;

;加拿大外交部尚未回应对该报告发表评论的请求。亚投行在回应有关皮卡德批评的问题时表示，该审查是“基于证据的”，并且维护了“多边治理的最高标准”。

;

;该审查还表示，“没有证据”表明这一点皮卡德要求亚投行保护他在职期间的安全，或防止他的安全受到任何威胁。

;

;但皮卡德表示，在与加拿大政府和警方沟通后，已决定尽快离开中国，甚至已他留下了钱包和大部分财产。

;

;他还表示，他曾与迈克尔·斯帕弗(Michael Spavor)进行过交谈，迈克尔·斯帕弗在华为高管孟晚舟及其同胞迈克尔·康明凯(Michael Kovrig)被捕后因间谍罪名被拘留。

;

; p>;

;“我就我的担忧咨询了政府。我们加拿大人对迈克尔两人的残暴绑架事件深受影响。我不想留下来寻找答案。”皮卡德补充道。

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 22:20:02 +0800 US-China relations: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says close cooperation vital for economy and to fight ‘existential threat’ of climate changehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3227032/us-china-relations-treasury-secretary-janet-yellen-says-close-cooperation-vital-economy-and-fight?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 21:24;
;;

;来访的财长耶伦强调美中需要保持沟通周六，合作应对气候变化的“生存威胁”。

;

;耶伦在北京钓鱼台国宾馆发表讲话时告诉中国副总理何立峰，两国在出现问题时应“直接”互动

;

;她表示，他们必须继续对话以避免误解，并“帮助双方更全面地了解全球经济前景，并做出更好的决策来加强我们的经济”。

;<去年双边贸易额达 6900 亿美元，耶伦表示：“尽管近期局势紧张，但我们在 2022 年创下了双边贸易纪录，这表明我们的企业有足够的空间参与贸易和投资。”

;

;她强调，华盛顿并不是采取赢家通吃的做法，也不是寻求对中国的经济优势，而是希望通过“公平的规则”确保良性竞争，使双方都受益。

;

;他回应说，北京对去年 11 月乔·拜登总统与习近平会晤后发生的“意外事件”破坏了改善中美关系的努力表示遗憾。

;

;美国财长耶伦访华有何期待

;

;“两国元首共识的落实存在一些问题，”他表示，但没有进一步详细说明。

;

;二月份，美国军方击落了一个所谓的间谍气球，国务卿安东尼·布林肯取消了对中国的访问计划。这次访问最终于上个月进行，五角大楼上周表示气球没有收集到任何信息。

;

;耶伦将在中国度过四天，作为双方努力修复紧张关系的一部分。在周五与李强总理会面时，耶伦表示，她希望她的中国之行能够“促进更多正常的沟通渠道”。

;

;周六早些时候，耶伦在与中国和国际气候专家交谈时表示，世界气候变化正在发生变化。两个最大的经济体必须共同努力应对全球变暖，并补充说，之前的合作，例如 2015 年《巴黎协定》，使全球突破成为可能。

;

;“作为世界上两个最大的温室气体排放国和最大的投资者在可再生能源领域，我们有共同的责任和能力来引领潮流，”耶伦说道，并补充说气候变化是“全球挑战的首要问题”。

;

;两国政府都希望她说，支持新兴市场和发展中国家努力实现气候目标。

;

;她还要求北京支持绿色气候基金和气候投资基金等多边气候机构，以实现“更大的气候变化”。 ”。

;

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Knockoff luxury items no longer taboo as Gen Z shoppers embrace ‘superfake’ designer bags, shoeshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3227031/knockoff-luxury-items-no-longer-taboo-gen-z-shoppers-embrace-superfake-designer-bags-shoes?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 21:17;
;;

;There is a new type of knock-off that is making it even harder to ensure your Gucci handbag or Yeezy sneakers are authentic.

;

;Designer brands have been combating knock-offs for decades, but a rising category of “superfakes” can trick the most experienced experts. Fabricators have become increasingly savvy at making a product look eerily similar to the real thing.

;

;Here is how superfakes became so difficult to tell apart from the real thing.

;

;Are luxury Chanel and Hermès bags really a good investment? 7 expert tips

;

;

;

;While knock-offs of designer clothing and accessories have been around for more than a century, they gained prominence in the 80s and 90s as logos became a status symbol on everything from Juicy Couture tracksuits to Tommy Hilfiger bucket hats.

;

;Those who could not afford the designer price tags went to thriving street markets like Canal Street in New York City, where sellers hawk counterfeit handbags, wallets, and shoes. Most of these fakes were not fooling anyone. They may have had a Gucci or Chanel logo, but they were cheaply made and often had telltale signs of inauthenticity, like fake leather, inconsistent stitching, or low-quality hardware.

;

;Knock-offs have a long history. Genuine and counterfeit Dior bags are displayed at the Counterfeit Museum in Paris in 2009. Superfakes have taken the practice to a new level.

;

;But superfakes are not your Canal Street knock-off. Chinese manufacturers have become increasingly skilled at replicating designer goods in such detail that even the most experienced authenticators can struggle to decipher a superfake.

;

;According to a New York Times article, these manufacturers are known to source leather from some of the same Italian suppliers as the fashion houses and often buy the real designer handbags to study how they are made.

;

;Social media and the pandemic's e-commerce boom have bolstered the knock-off market. Gen Z consumers are increasingly interested in luxury products and are fuelling a movement that embraces knock-offs as subversive.

;

;These young shoppers, born between 1997 and 2012, wear fakes with pride. They have decided that is cool to buy dupes and knock-offs, opposed to previous generations that deemed them taboo. TikTok puts Gen Z's obsession on full display; there are thousands of videos on where to shop for dupes of handbags, cosmetics, and sneakers.

;

;It is important to note that dupes and knock-offs are not the same. A dupe is simply a cheaper product that looks similar to a designer item, but does not infringe on a brand's intellectual property or trademark.

;

;However, any product that intentionally replicates a brand's product, using its logo, name, or intellectual property is considered a knock-off. Selling counterfeits is illegal in the US and in some countries, such as France and Italy, it is illegal to wear them.

;

;While they are cheaper than the real thing, superfakes are more expensive than an average knock-off. The price of a real Hermes Birkin bag starts at US$10,000, while a superfake can cost up to US$2,000.

;

;Buying a superfake handbag also is not as easy as purchasing an average knock-off. According to a TikTok video by creator Charles Gross, you usually have to know someone who has bought a superfake to get a seller's contact information.

;

;There are also Reddit threads devoted to the best sellers. Typically, bags are made to order and the seller sends quality-control photos throughout the process.

;

;In 2020, the fashion industry lost more than US$50 billion in potential sales because of counterfeit merchandise. Both designer brands and third-party marketplaces have invested millions in combating counterfeits, but the issue is so widespread that it is impossible to stop them all.

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Climate scientists cover Sichuan’s Dagu glaciers with Tencent-sponsored hi-tech blanket to impede their melt amid global warminghttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3226846/climate-scientists-cover-sichuans-dagu-glaciers-tencent-sponsored-hi-tech-blanket-impede-their-melt?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 19:00;
;;

;A giant blanket has gone up over a portion of China's most accessible glacier to slow its melting, as climate scientists race to stem their retreat amid global warming.

;

;At the Dagu glaciers in the Tibetan region of southwestern China's Sichuan province, thick rolls of white sheets now cover an area of over 400 square metres. Supported by poles and anchored with wooden boards, the sheets feature a newly developed film that achieves radiative cooling, which scientists hope can slow down the melting rate of Dagu's glaciers.

;

;“Our material is lighter in texture, water-repellent, more eco-friendly, and can be reused multiple times,” said the Nanjing University's associate professor Zhu Bin, during a visit two weeks ago to the area. “The cost of it is also on par with traditional geotextiles.”

;

;Zhu leads a team supported by the university's three-year partnership with the Tencent Carbon Neutral Lab, a unit set up in 2021 by the world's biggest video games publisher Tencent Holdings.

;

;The team is racing against time to slow down the melting of glaciers, fighting a losing game to retard, if not entirely stop the process. Floods that burst out from glacial lakes when glaciers melt threaten 15 million people around the world, putting 1 million at risk in western China's Xinjiang, Tibet, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan regions, according to a study.

;

;About 8,000 glaciers, or 15 per cent of the total in China, have melted in the past 50 years due to global warming, according to calculations by Kang Shichang, the director of the State Key Laboratory of Cryosphere Sciences at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the country's national science think tank.

;

;Half of the Earth's 215,000 glaciers could disappear entirely by 2100 – with ramifications for the world's supply of fresh water and ecosystems – even if humanity can successfully curb global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, according to research published in the Science journal in January.

;

;Although China has committed to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to reach carbon neutrality by 2060, the country's meteorological administration announced last month that the El Niño climate phenomenon is expected to bring more extreme weather, including record high temperatures, to China.

;

;Evidence of global warming is everywhere, even at Dagu, which has become a popular tourist destination since the glaciers were first discovered in 1992 through satellite imagery. Thousands of tourists throng the area – six hours drive from Chengdu – all-year round, paying 180 yuan (US$25) each for a 15-minute ride in the world's highest cable car to reach a viewing platform located 4,860 metres (15,944 feet) above sea level.

;

;Only 11 glaciers covering 1.46 square kilometres remain at Dagu, from 17 spanning 5.6 square kilometres as recently as 1971, according to the Dagu Glacier Management Bureau's deputy head Huang Shihai. The volume of the glacier, located by the Heishui River, has shrunk by more than 70 per cent over half a century, he said.

;

;“When I first came here in 2006, the length and width of the glacier were still quite impressive,” said Huang, 43 years old. “I've almost never worn short-sleeve shirts before 2013, but nowadays I need to wear one during the hottest days in July and August.”

;

;Glacier blankets are not exactly new. Swiss and Italian scientists have been using geotextiles and tarpaulins to cover glaciers in the Alps from the sun's rays for almost two decades. The technique can reduce snow and ice melting by between 50 per cent and 70 per cent, according to Matthias Huss, the director of the Swiss Glacier Monitoring Network and a senior scientist at ETH Zürich in Switzerland.

;

;Nanjing University's material reflects more radiation and radiates more heat, Zhu said. In experiments carried out in 2021 at Glacier No. 1 at the Tianshan mountains in Xinjiang region, Zhu covered 200 square metres of snow with his new material. The result, published last February in the peer-reviewed Science Advances journal, found that the melt was reduced by 1.5 metres over 50 days, or three to four times better than traditional materials, Zhu said.

;

;“Mitigation and adaptation are two major strategies to deal with climate change,” said Xu Hao, head of Tencent's Carbon Neutral Lab. “Both are complementary to each other and very important.”

;

;The material used at Dagu is even better, due to upgrades, Zhu said. When the northern hemisphere summer ends in September, his team will return to Dagu to remove the blanket and assess their result.

;

;“The method has the potential to preserve ice locally, but not to fight against climate change,” said Huss. “It will never be possible to cover a large [glacier] or all glaciers, just to save them.”

;

;Blankets, however advanced they are, are not “scalable” to save the entire glacier. “The cost of such an endeavour would be huge and completely uneconomic,” he said, adding that widespread and large-scale use could damage surrounding ecosystems.

;

;These materials are best used to preserve the ice at specific locations where it is absolutely needed for snow-related tourism such as ski slopes. Cutting the emission of greenhouse gases is a far more efficient way of saving glacial ice, not to mention reducing all the other negative impacts of human-induced warming, he said.

;

;“Local interaction does not stop glacier retreat,” Huss said. “There's only one way we can save all glaciers, and thus avoid negative impacts: It's by saving the climate.”

;On the 500th day since Russia's invasion and as the war grinds on, Ukrainian forces are advancing slowly without enough arms and ammunition and with its main cities under constant threat.

;Since the beginning of June, Ukraine's army has been on the offensive to reconquer territory captured by Russian forces in the east and the south.

;

;At a street market in Nikopol, Lyudmila Shudinova, 82, said her thoughts were focused on her 49-year-old son, a volunteer fighter recovering from a wound.

;

;She said she had come to buy him potatoes.

;

;“I am very scared that, after he heals, he will again be sent to the front,” she said, with tears in her eyes.

;

;Ukrainians remain united in the effort to repel Russian forces but their resilience is constantly being tested.

;

;The UN has documented the deaths of 9,000 civilians, including more than 500 children, in the conflict so far. The real toll could be much higher.

;

;Russia unleashes biggest drone attack on Ukraine's Kyiv since start of war

;

;Despite a significant strengthening of Ukraine's air defence capability this year, the threat of drone and missile attacks across the country is constant.

;

;In June, a missile hit a restaurant in Kramatorsk in the east killing 13 people, and on Thursday 10 people were killed in a strike on the western city of Lviv, which has so far been spared the daily bombardment of other parts of Ukraine.

;

;The city of Nikopol near the front line in the south is also regularly hit by Russian forces and half of its pre-war population of 100,000 people has left.

;

;It lies on the western shore of the Kakhovka reservoir – just 10km from the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power station which has been under the control of Russian forces since March 2022.

;

;In the last few days, the threat of a nuclear disaster has loomed large in the region as Moscow and Kyiv accuse each other of preparing to blow up the plant.

;

;The region has already been badly hit by an explosion at the Kakhovka dam on June 6 which caused significant flooding and killed dozens of people.

;

;Ukraine has accused Russia of blowing up the dam intentionally to slow down the counteroffensive.

;

;Upstream from the dam, the Kakhovka reservoir – 100km long and up to 10km wide – is running low.

;

;Several areas, like Nikopol, have had their drinking water cut as a result.

;

;Wearing an elegant white hat under a baking hot sun, Morakhovska spoke to AFP at a water distribution point to fill up some canisters with drinking water.

;

;An air raid siren went off as Morakhovska spoke, provoking an emotional reaction from the Nikopol resident living under constant threat of Russian bombardment.

;

;“When the alarm goes off like that, I always think the same thing. May you (Russian) bastards all die,” she said.

;The head of the United Nations' nuclear watchdog was met with protests while visiting South Korea on Saturday in a bid to calm fears over Japan's plan to discharge treated radioactive water from its tsunami-hit Fukushima plant.

;

;Rafael Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), arrived in Seoul on Friday to meet Foreign Minister Park Jin and a top nuclear safety official during his three-day visit after wrapping up a trip to Japan.

;

;Earlier in the week, the IAEA said that a two-year review showed Japan's plans for the water release would have a negligible impact on the environment.

;

;His arrival at Seoul's Gimpo Airport was met with protests, local media reported, despite the South Korean government's announcement that it respected the IAEA's report and that its own analysis had found the release will not have “any meaningful impact” on its waters.

;

;Hundreds of people including members of the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions took to the streets on Saturday to protest the discharge plan.

;

;“It makes little sense to argue that the release is OK because it does not harm humans. Animals also live in the ocean,” said university student Kim Han-bi.

;

;No expert behind the IAEA's Fukushima report disagreed with the content, Grossi said on Saturday, hinting at his comment during an interview with Reuters one day earlier that one or two team members may have expressed concerns.

;

;On Sunday, Grossi is set to meet with members of the opposition Democratic Party of Korea which has been critical of the Japanese plan.

;

;The administration of President Yoon Suk-yeol has walked a fine line in its stance to Japan's discharge proposal, as it tries to improve ties with Tokyo. But the plan has stirred anger and concern among South Koreans, prompting some shoppers to buy up sea salt.

;

;Despite South Korea's assent for the plan, a ban on food and seafood products from the Fukushima region would remain in place.

;

;Opposition Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung has also said the government should try to halt the plan and take the case to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea.
